the raw beautiful fierce power of birth is awe inspiring our bodies are amazing
blood water mess dont give a damn pushing pushing must keep pushing then a cry to melt hearts one more push done relief love love love forever
feeling the urge to push not bloody waiting for the midwife on all fours roaring duncan squeezing a cold flannel on my neck bliss midwives arriving fetal heartbeat good
the birthing pool had been sitting in our dining room inflated for the best part of a month finally that night i was finally woken by that odd crunching contraction feeling
throwing up in the downstairs loo passing out mid contraction hoping the midwife would arrive soon
calls to my mum my sister and the midwife duncan filling the pool dancing to my birth playlist in the front room to distract myself from the contractions rocking the tens machine
when it happened again minutes later i woke duncan and we went downstairs put the kettle on to make a cuppa and see what would unfold
at worst i figured the reflexology would be a nice foot massage it was lovely carrying all that extra weight takes its toll on your toes
i had run out of ridiculous things to clean in the house doorstep fridge wall beside the dishwasher and was ready to meet my baby
one year ago today it was similarly very hot ten days overdue sick of consuming curry amp pineapple juice i had reflexology to try to kickstart the labour process

for the conservatives same sex marriage was all they needed to do to be able to say they d done something for lgbt rights for them it was another box ticked they didn t want to upset their backbench dinosaurs any more for equality
same sex marriage bill was one of the proudest lib dem achievements from coalition for us it was a big step toward equality with recognition that more needed to be done in the uk and around the world
the answer was no again and the following year when i was on maternity leave jenny willott was not allowed to go to the same event again

a few days later the same sex marriage bill came back to the commons for report stage so i thought the conservatives were just trying to avoid another row with backbenchers at a difficult time so i asked if we could sign the statement later in the year with less fanfare
but i was just told no our advisers got involved and we even tried to get nick to speak to cameron but the pm was out of the country and we just didn t have enough time
i was told the uk could no longer sign the statement no reason given i asked if there were any changes we could make at this late stage so that we could sign
the conservatives were copied in all along as the doc was drafted didn t bat an eyelid then suddenly just days before i was due to travel
my colleague who was leading the efforts on the same sex marriage bill had initiated a document that called for action on lgbt rights which was to be signed by the ministers at this event

but i am truly furious when she tries to suggest that it is in any way possible to protect employment rights from the axe of a future conservative prime minister who could tear up any legal commitment she makes now

when theresa may tries to appropriate lib dem achievements like shared parental leave more flexible working or gender pay gap reporting i find it irritating given we had to fight tooth and nail against her tory colleagues at every turn to deliver these as she well knows

these battles were the product of many in the tory party seeing employment rights as unnecessary red tape something to be pared back constantly sacrificed on the altar of deregulation it makes no actual sense good business thrives when it treats staff well
you can argue about whether as lib dems we picked won or lost the right battles on workers rights in the coalition but what is not debatable is that these battles were constant

we stopped the tories extreme attempts to undermine the trade union movement after the tory majority they passed the trade union act  a nasty law based on scant evidence industrial relations positive trade union engagement actually having been a recent success story

we won battles to introduce naming shaming for firms that break minimum wage law and massively increased the resources for hmrc to clamp down on rogue employers paying less than the national minimum wage

we stopped the tories scrapping the equality human rights commission and the public sector equality duty but they succeeded in stalling measures on third party harassment protections and removing the ability for workers to get useful information

the tories were adamant about their new employment tribunal fees i tried to get them stopped but grayling refused to budge or even review the evidence of the dreadful impact eventually thankfully the supreme court struck these fees down as unlawful

then there was the ridiculous shares for rights scheme dreamt up by george osborne where people could give up employment rights in return for shares we managed to put protections in place so no one would be forced to do so but it really was a bonkers idea
beecroft included ideas like scrapping maternity rights and bosses being able to fire people for no good reason on a whim vince cable rightly told the tories to take a running jump

first there was the beecroft report though it was really more like a crap gcse essay attempt without proper evidence it was written by a tory donor though so they demanded the ideas in it were looked at
